factoid: Bilíbin said that he was not jesting.
Bilíbin said that nothing was truer or sadder.
The gentlemen rode onto the bridge alone and waved white handkerchiefs.
The gentlemen assured the officer on duty that they, the marshals, were on their way to negotiate with Prince Auersperg.
The officer on duty let the gentlemen enter the tête-de-pont.
The gentlemen spun the officer a thousand gasconades, saying that the war was over.
The gentlemen said that Emperor Francis was arranging a meeting with Bonaparte.
The gentlemen said that they desired to see Prince Auersperg.
The officer sent for Prince Auersperg.
The gentlemen embraced the officers.
The gentlemen cracked jokes.
The gentlemen sat on the cannon.
A French battalion reached the bridge unobserved.
The French battalion flung bags of incendiary material into the water.
The French battalion approached the tête-de-pont.
Prince Auersperg von Mautern appeared.
Prince Auersperg called the speaker Dearest foe.
Prince Auersperg called the speaker Flower of the Austrian army.
Prince Auersperg called the speaker hero of the Turkish wars.
Prince Auersperg said that hostilities were ended.
Prince Auersperg said that they could shake one another's hand.
Emperor Napoleon was impatient to make Prince Auersperg's acquaintance.
The gentlemen, who were Gascons, bewildered Prince Auersperg with fine words.
Prince Auersperg was flattered by his rapidly established intimacy with the French marshals.
Prince Auersperg was dazzled by the sight of Murat's mantle and ostrich plumes.
Prince Auersperg only saw fire and forgot the enemy he should have fired upon.
Bilíbin paused after his speech to give time for appreciation.
The French battalion rushed to the bridgehead.
The French battalion spiked the guns.
The bridge was taken by the French battalion.
Bilíbin said that the best part was that the sergeant in charge of the cannon was about to fire but was stopped by Lannes.
The sergeant in charge of the cannon was about to fire the mines and blow up the bridge.
The sergeant saw that the French troops were running onto the bridge.
Lannes stayed the sergeant's hand.
The sergeant, who was wiser than his general, went up to Prince Auersperg and said that Prince Auersperg was being deceived and that the French were present.
Murat saw that all was lost if the sergeant was allowed to speak.
Murat turned to Prince Auersperg with feigned astonishment.
Murat said that he did not recognize the world-famous Austrian discipline if a subordinate addressed Prince Auersperg in that manner.
Prince Auersperg ordered the sergeant to be arrested.
Prince Auersperg described the affair of the Thabor Bridge as delightful.
Prince Auersperg said that the affair was not exactly stupidity nor rascality.
Bilíbin said that it may be treachery to Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew imagined gray overcoats, wounds, smoke of gunpowder, sounds of firing, and the glory that awaited him.
Bilíbin replied that it was not treachery and that it would put the court in too bad a light.
Bilíbin said that it was not treachery, nor rascality, nor stupidity.
Bilíbin said that it was just as at Ulm.
Bilíbin said that it was a bit of Mack and that they were Macked.
Bilíbin concluded that he had produced a good epigram.
Bilíbin's previously puckered brow became smooth as a sign of pleasure.
Bilíbin began to examine his nails.
Bilíbin asked Prince Andrew where he was off to.
Prince Andrew replied that he was going away.
Prince Andrew said that he was going to the army.
Bilíbin asked Prince Andrew whether he had meant to stay another two days.
Prince Andrew replied that he was now off at once.
Prince Andrew gave directions about his departure and went to his room.
Bilíbin followed Prince Andrew and said that he had been thinking about him and asked why he was going.
Bilíbin's wrinkles vanished from his face.
Prince Andrew looked inquiringly at Bilíbin and gave no reply.
